title: 113_s1415
content: The Act is titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" and includes definitions for various terms used within the Act. The Act defines "Federal land" as approximately 17,826 acres depicted on a specific map and "planning area" as land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in various districts. The Act defines "Federal land" as approximately 17,826 acres on a specific map and "planning area" as land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in different districts, including Coos Bay, Eugene, Medford, Roseburg, Salem, and Klamath Falls Resource Area of the Lakeview District. Public domain land is defined in this subsection. The Act defines "public domain land" as land not managed in accordance with the Act of August 28, 1937, excluding specific districts like Coos Bay, Eugene, Medford, Roseburg, Salem, and Klamath Falls Resource Area of the Lakeview District. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 defines "public lands" and excludes lands managed under the Act of August 28, 1937. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "Tribe" refers to the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE. The United States will transfer Federal land to the Tribe, including improvements, minerals, and rights-of-way. A survey will establish the boundaries within 180 days. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary must file a map and legal description of Federal land with specified committees, with the same force and effect as if included in the Act, allowing for corrections of errors. The Secretary must file a map and legal description of Federal land with specified committees, having the same force and effect as if included in the Act, allowing for corrections of errors. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection in the Office of the Secretary. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. Unless expressly provided in this Act, existing tribal rights to land are preserved. Federal laws on exporting unprocessed logs from Federal land apply. Land taken into trust cannot be used for gaming activities under Public Law 100-497. Forest management on Federal land must comply with all relevant Federal laws. Land reclassification is also addressed in the legislation. The legislation requires the identification of Oregon and California Railroad land to be conveyed, as well as the identification of public domain land of similar acreage and condition within a specific planning area. Maps must be provided within two years of the enactment of the Act. "After enactment, the Secretary must identify public domain land equal in acreage and condition to the Oregon and California Railroad land within the planning area. Maps depicting the identified land must be submitted to Congress and published within 2 years. The Secretary will reclassify the identified land as owned by the Oregon and California Railroad after public comment." After identifying public domain land equal in acreage and condition to the Oregon and California Railroad land, the Secretary will reclassify it as owned by the railroad after public comment. The Act requires submission of maps depicting the identified land to Congress and publication in the Federal Register.
